page.title: 05The history of Gwynfryn
page.content: Gwynfryn village stands on a limestone ridge.It is over a thousand feet above sea level.In English the name Gwynfryn means White Hill. Some people say that this is because of the colour of the limestone but others think it might be because , in winter, it is often white with snow. Many years ago there were a large number of quarries and lead mines worked in the area and because people came to work in them the village grew.The good quality stone from the quarries was used to build some of Liverpool's best known buildings but there is only one quarry working today -that's the Tarmac Roadstone Quarry. There are many abandoned lead mine shafts in the area and this makes it dangerous for children and animals.
